bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, February 4, 1923

div1.p: Connor reports extensively on the yellow fever campaign in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, February 4, 1923
div1.opener:
N. H. B
Oficina de Sanided.
Merida Lucatan Mexico.
February 4th. 1 9 2 3.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
A copy of your letter to Mr. LePrince in answer
to his without date, comes to me this morning. The article to which
LePrince refers is my final report on yellow fever control in Merida
and which was published in the Journal (American) of Tropical Medicine
in November last.

I did not know that the Board had authorized the pub-
lication of this report. When reprints are received I will send one om
to you.

Doctor White passed through Progreso yesterday on his
way to the States and no doubt you will soon see him and he will give
at first hand the status of the campaign which seems to me to be going
along very nicely.

Last month there was a case reported from the oil fields
near Panuco. Dr. White considers it very doubtful but the case will I
believe be officially announced as yellow fever. The entire area around
Panuco and extending to Tuxpam is I understand to be gone over again by
Dr. Scannell and this inspection should prove to be very interesting.

I have discussed with Dr. White, and I think he agrees
with me, that we have reached a period in the campaign where a laboratory and a
good laboratory man would be of inestimable aid, more especially a man
that has been trained under Noguchi and cando the Pffifier reaction.
Do you regard this test as postive indetermining whether onone has had
yellow fever? The Trager case clinically was considered as a heavey e.a.
infection yet Noguchi reports a positive Pfiffer whereas the Coss case
was finally diagnosed as Y.F. and Noguchi reports a negative Pfiffer.
If this reaction is reasonably accurate it will be of great aid to us
here especially when the malaria season begins again.

Progreso and some other towns have experienced an increase
of malaria cases in the latter of 1922 and there were quite a few deaths in
very young children and very old people. The type was tertian withall the
classical symptoms, herpes, enlarged spleen, vomiting of greatquanitities of
bile but no blood. There followed profound anemia in some cases and a
jaundice which was more marked in the sclerae. The unfortunate part of
this outbreak was that the poor people had no money to buy quinine and the
municipalities would not furnish it.

C1
B22

I have completed a second inspection trip of the interior towns and
am unable to find or hear of any cases resembling yellow fever and aswe
have had an increased movement of people from the highlands og Mexico and
developments amongst them I am inclined to think that the situation here
has been dominated. We are not however relaxing our work in the least and
to keep going here at top speed so long as there is a case anywhere in Mexico.

The more I study the stegomyia in relation to the aljibe the more
convinced am I that the aljibe is beyond doubt the ideal breeding place
for this specie of mosquito, and wherever the fish die in analjibe and the
stegomyia seems to know it and at once pounces upon the aljibe and lay
a batch of eggs, never have I found an aljibe breeding mosquitoes with a
mojarra in it. Unfortunately many people take the fish out and before we
know what has happened in that aljibe, it is breeding we now test out each aljibe on each
cycle of inspection by dropping a small piece of tortilla or white bread into
it and if the mojarra is living it will dart after the material, if not we
order another fish to be placed therein, and thus make sure of that con-
tainer.

Did I write you that the Stegomyia will not deposit eggs in Lejia when
the lejia is in a copper container. It is a fact they will not. I asked
Richardson, our Inspector at Tampico to paint the inside of a tin container
with copper paint and note the results. He did and for a period of one
month did not observe any mosquitos in that container. Before using
copper paint I suggested the use of pieces of copper in the lejia and the
results were very encouraging but the trouble appears to be the indifference
of the people to place the copper when making new lejia. Richardson has
noted that some houseswives were using using pieces of orange or lime skins
for the purpose of keeping the 'moscas' out of the lejia and they claim that
it can be done with this. In Merida we are recommending to the people that all containers
other than copper receptacles, to place pieces of orange or lime skins there-
in and to my surprise they are doing it as they claim that these fruit skins
increase the life of the lejia, this maybe the solution to the lejia prob-
lem. I hope so.

I will be leaving Merida this month to go to Colima to close that
office as Dr. Cassasus has reported to Dr. White that the former endemic
center is now eliminated and Dr. White sees no need of continuing the station,
after this I will make t trip to Nueva Lareua, Matamoras, Ciudad Victoria
and adjoining places for purpose of inspecting same.

I have a lot of data, epidemiological, which I will try to work up into a
readable paper later in the year and am wondering if you would do me the
great favor of reading and critising it before I send it in. The Mexican
situation has been vastly different, not in the fundamentals, but in the area
infected and the rapidity and ease with which in the infection has travelled
-3-
from place to place. The infection has gone around in a circle as it were,
first as a mild type which at times was quite completely masked by the
malaria infection and only coming to our notice when it reached the large
centers. It appears to me that there have been many temporary endemic
centers that we have no knowledge of whatever and in in collecting data of
these sparsely setlled areas I am quite convinced that there operated the
factors, unnoticed by anyone, of a constant movement of a very small number of
people to these temporary endemic centers such as I have observee in the
oil fields where the geoligists go into new country establish temporary
headquarters which becomes a sort of hotel for people passing thru that
region. You know that geologist are watched and when they leave headquarters
they are followed first by native spies, then wait by white men and in due
time there is a constant stream of non-immunes, going into an area that was
hardly spoken of before their event.

Somyime ago you sent me a copy of your latest writing, for Nelson's loose
leaf medical library, on yellow fever in which you divide endemiicity
as follows: Endemic and Permanently Endemic, Do you still hold to this
division? Doesn't the word endemic as you are using it carry with it the idea, to the
average person, of greater or longer ppermanency than would the term Temporary
Endemicity or temporarily endemic; and doesn't custon sanction the inference
to mean permanency?

In your future writings will you xxxx refer to the 'stegomyia' as the Aedes
Egyptus of Calopus? Would it be better to drop the name 'stegomyia' alto-
gether. I do not like to do it for the reason that in Latin America the
intelligent part of the public know the 'stegomyia' and its relation to
yellow fever, and therefore it is easier for us in publicity to convey to
the public what we are doing.

Refering to mosquito indices I am of the opinion that the Deposit index
is of more value to the Director of a campaign in the early weeks of his
work and once the situation has been controlled a pupaeindex should be
started, as it is at that time the Director should know somthing definitely
about the adult production and the larvae index really does not tell him
much of anything because all the larvae noted will presumably be destroyed
by the Inspector finding them whereas with a pupae index you really get some
thing tangible but not necssarily correct data. The more accurate data on
adult production will come from a recheck of a district by a special man
and for this purpose I always try to nominate a Revisador and at intervals
I recheck the Revisador myself.

On the development of an organization in yellow fever campaign
In a phamphlet/which I have submitted to the Home and suggested publication
I stress the point that the mosquito indices is not to be relied upon in
arriving at a decision as to the presence or absence of
yellow fever in a community. Hereafter I am not using the term safety-
index, it is misleading, I may use the term 'relative safety-index' meaning
thereby that a stage in the campaign has been reached indicating that the
stegomyia has been reduced a favorable minimum as based on the indices of
-4-
of other countires hwere anti-larvae measures against the stegomyia have
been practiced but will lay emphasis on the fact the index of one community is
not accurate criteria for another community.

Lyster when in charge of the Mexican campaign was wont to stress the point
that endemicity and I suppose he meant permanent endemicity, was only possible
in large centers. I think I have seen evidence here in Mexico where endemicity
lasting several years in relatively small communities kept up by the constant
stream of non-immunes, never in large numbers at any one time, but at the
right intervals to keep the infection alive. What I am trying to get at is that
the general impression has been and is that endemicity can only be established
in large communities whereas my idea is that endemicity is determined in a great
measure by the movement of the people with-out regard as to numbers and in a small community
the interval of arrival is the of the non-immunes is thea principal factor in
maintaining endemicity in that small community. The 'wall of immunity' mentioned
by Giteras is protection to the new-comerin proportion to the number of people
making up that 'wall' which are relatively few in the average small town in
Mexico where the vast majority of homes are detached and social inter
course scant. All of which brings us to the point of whether, in Mexico, it
would not have been the right thing to have started sweeping our areas from
the begining of the campaign rather than to have depended upon the self-elimina
tion of the infection in the small community while we were working in the so-
called 'key-centers'. The fact has been that the infection was flourish
ing in small communities, in a mild form to begin with, near our key centers and
we did not know it and these communities were closeenough or rather the cummica
tion was that easy that the infection went around in a circle and would have kept
up indefinitely had it not assumed the severe type of virulency and there was
no mistaking the diagnosis.
I am returning LePrince's letter to you.

When you have the time I will be glad to receive your opinion on the points
brought up here and as I am to do some travelling over the country this year
your letter should be addressed to the Home Office.
With all good wishes and the kindliest personal regards,

closer.salute: I am, as ever, your friend
